titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Martha Baird Rockefeller papers FA467

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-16 01:33:29 -0400.

did.physdesc: Housing -- Boxes 1-28 - document boxes. Boxes 29-30 - oversized flat boxes. All other boxes are record cartons.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Martha Baird Rockefeller (March 15, 1895 - January 24, 1971), the second wife and widow of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., was a world-class classical pianist in the 1920s, giving concerts across the U.S. and throughout Europe.

Martha Baird was born in Madera, California, the second child of William F. Baird (1861-1916), a coal operator and merchant, and the former Mina A. Smith (1862-1903), a musician. Martha's first public performance was in June 1903, when, at the age of 8, she played "In the Gypsies' Camp" on piano in a concert at the University of Southern California's College of Music, where her mother taught piano and organ. Martha studied with Morton F. Mason, a composer and organist in southern California. She graduated from the Blairsville (Pennsylvania) School for Girls and attended Occidental College in Los Angeles. In 1915 she entered the New England Conservatory of Music. In May 1917 she won the school's annual piano competition, which earned her a $1,200 grand piano as the grand prize. That spring she graduated with highest honors from the school's soloist course.

On November 14, 1917, Martha Baird gave her first public recital at Boston's Jordan Hall. Her performance was well received by the Boston Globe but Philip Hall of the Boston Herald thought that she had "not yet learned to think musically at all times for herself." On March 22, 1920, Martha Baird made her New York debut at the Princess Theater at 104 West 39th Street. On August 4, 1920, she married Adrian van Laar, an importer; they divorced in Paris in 1925. During her marriage, Martha Baird continued to perform under her own name, and on October 5, 1923, "the famous American pianist" made her debut in London at Wigmore Hall.

On May 20, 1930, in the study of Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, Martha Baird was married to Arthur M. Allen, a lawyer, of Providence, Rhode Island. Some discussions of her career indicate that she retired from performing after her marriage to Allen, but she did not stop entirely. By the mid-1930s her appearances were concentrated around Boston and Providence, and she devoted more time to the Providence Symphony Orchestra, especially its concerts for young people. In May 1937 she was elected president of the Providence Community Concert Association, serving in that capacity until 1950. In 1940 she wrote the music to accompany Helen Church's lyrics for the Republican party campaign anthem, "We Want Willkie."

Arthur Allen died on May 6, 1950. On August 15, 1951, Martha Baird Allen married John D. Rockefeller, Jr., whose wife Abby had died in 1948. Arthur Allen had been a Brown University classmate and a friend of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., so that Martha Baird had known JDR Jr. for some time. As a wedding present, JDR Jr. gave his bride a trust fund so that she could experience the joy of giving that he had known.

Martha Baird Rockefeller used her new wealth, and the $48 million she inherited upon her husband's death in 1960, to support her chosen field of music as well as causes identified with the Rockefeller family. In 1957, she established the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, a private philanthropy that responded to various needs she saw in the field of music. Incorporated in 1962, the Fund's interest centered on young solo artists, who received support directly through individual grants or indirectly through contributions to performance organizations that offered advanced training and employment in important capacities. Until Mrs. Rockefeller's death in 1971, the Fund was supported by her contributions of $600,000 annually. Her will provided for an unrestricted bequest to the fund of $5,000,000, and the trustees elected to continue the program at the same level until funds were exhausted. The Fund was dissolved in 1982.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Standard archival processing to arrange, describe and preserve a portion of the Martha Baird Rockefeller papers records was conducted by Joseph W. Ernst and the staff of the Rockefeller family archives, as well as staff of the Rockefeller Archive Center.
Series 1, Subseries 12 Rockefeller family correspondence and Subseries 13 Political remain in their original folders
Series 5, Series 6, Series 7 and Series 8 currently remain in their original folders and original storage boxes.

The original finding aid was prepared by Joseph W. Ernst and the staff of the Rockefeller family archives, prior to the physical shipment of the material to the Rockefeller Archive Center in 1982. Front matter was compiled in 2014, at which time the finding aid was digitally converted into the RAC collection management system.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Inc. donated the Martha Baird Rockefeller papers to the Rockefeller Archive Center in January 1982. The papers were initially transferred to the Rockefeller Family Archives (Rockefeller Family & Associates) in April 1971 and June 1972 at which time a preliminary appraisal was conducted and the material was accessioned. The Martha Baird Rockefeller papers were then physically transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center on January 14, 1982.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.
The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Martha Baird Rockefeller papers consist of correspondence, scrapbooks, photo albums, personal memoranda books, house books, and sheet music. The majority of these papers were maintained at her home by Martha Rockefeller or her personal staff and were never part of files maintained at the Rockefeller Family Office in Room 5600 of Rockefeller Center (except Series 4).

The Martha Baird Rockefeller papers also contain financial and estate records, plus office files created and maintained by Mary Packard. Series 4 consists of Martha Baird Rockefeller's files maintained at Room 5600.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series 1: Correspondence. Subseries 1: Individuals. Subseries 2: Organizations. Subseries 3: Baird family. Subseries 4: Martha Baird Rockefeller personal. Subseries 5: Possessions. Subseries 6: Osteopathy. Subseries 7: Medicine. Subseries 8: Giving Program. Subseries 9: Homes. Subseries 10: Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music. Subseries 11: Rockefeller family philanthropy. Subseries 12: Rockefeller family correspondence. Subseries 13: Political.
Series 2: Scrapbooks and Photo Albums. Series 3: Personal Memoranda Books and House Books. Series 4: Room 5600 (Rockefeller family office) File. Series 5: Office Files (Mary Packard files)

Series 6: Private, Financial, and Estate Inventories, Appraisals & Distributions. Subseries 1: Medicine. Subseries 2: Trusts. Subseries 3: MBR Will. Subseries 4: Accounts. Subseries 5: 740 Park Avenue. Subseries 6: Political. Subseries 7: JDR Jr. Estate. Subseries 8: MBR Estate. Subseries 9: Card Catalouges.
Series 7: Clippings and Annual Reports. Series 8: Piano Music.
The files contained in Series 1-3 were placed in their present file arrangement by Martha Baird Rockefeller.
